message.content:
cs.DB, cs.DC, cs.SE, cs.DS, cs.PL. 

The paper discusses a novel provenance framework that marries database-style and workflow-style provenance, using Pig Latin to expose the functionality of modules and capturing internal state and fine-grained dependencies. This suggests a focus on data management and processing, making cs.DB the most likely sub-category. The paper also discusses graph transformation operations and workflow analytic queries, which are relevant to sub-categories such as cs.DC (Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing) and cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms). The use of Pig Latin and Lipstick system also suggests a focus on programming languages and software engineering, making cs.SE a likely sub-category. Finally, the paper's title references Pig Latin, which is a language for processing large datasets, suggesting a possible fit with cs.PL (Programming Languages).
